repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This resolves all occurrences of the msvc warning `C4127: conditional expression is constant` I could find.

comment_data.body:
This might be the cleaner solution
```cpp
#if PY_MAJOR_VERSION >= 3
    module = PyImport_ImportModule("collections.abc");
#else
    module = PyImport_ImportModule("collections");
#endif
```

This probably wants to be inline.

I also don't think it fits into the general naming scheme that Cython adopts (probably should start with `__Pyx`, all upper-case implies macro).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef CYTHON_CONDITION
+  int CYTHON_CONDITION_IMPL(int b) { return b; }

comment_data.body: I will update the name. Where should I place the macro, so it does has access to `CYTHON_INLINE`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef CYTHON_CONDITION
+  int CYTHON_CONDITION_IMPL(int b) { return b; }

comment_data.body: Should the macro name start with `CYTHON` or `__PYX`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef CYTHON_CONDITION
+  int CYTHON_CONDITION_IMPL(int b) { return b; }

comment_data.body: We use `CYTHON_*` for (user visible) configuration related macros and case variants of `__Pyx_*` for anything that's internal. This seems internal.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef CYTHON_CONDITION
+  int CYTHON_CONDITION_IMPL(int b) { return b; }

comment_data.body: Is it time for a `__Pyx_MIN_PY_VERSION()` macro? (Just asking…)

Hm I would like something along the lines of
```cpp
#define __Pyx_PY_VERSION_HEX(MAJOR_VERSION, MINOR_VERSION, MICRO_VERSION, RELEASE_LEVEL, RELEASE_SERIAL, ...) \
   ((MAJOR_VERSION << 24) | \
    (MINOR_VERSION << 16) | \
    (MICRO_VERSION <<  8) | \
    (RELEASE_LEVEL <<  4) | \
    (RELEASE_SERIAL << 0))

#define __Pyx_PY_VERSION_GT(...) \
    (PY_VERSION_HEX > __Pyx_PY_VERSION_HEX(__VA_ARGS__, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0))
```
Which could be used e.g. as
```
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_GT(3)
```
However this would not work on c89/C++98 :/

I think if these macros are used they should be used for all operators:
```
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_LT()
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_LE()
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_EQ()
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_NE()
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_GE()
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_GT()
```
I do not know whether either of
```
__Pyx_PY_VERSION_GE(3, 6, 0, PY_RELEASE_LEVEL_BETA, 1)
```
is much of an improvement over
```
PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030600B1
```

I think virtually all version comparisons that we have can be reduced to `PY_VERSION_HEX >= …` (and the tiny rest can just stay as it is). I also think it's fine to stick with the hex number. C level features/changes/incompatibilities are always introduced in some patch level version of CPython, and the hex version is a good way to express that.

Should it be
```
#define __Pyx_MIN_PY_VERSION(VERSION_HEX) (PY_VERSION_HEX >= VERSION_HEX)
```
which works everywhere, or
```
#define __Pyx_MIN_PY_VERSION(VERSION_HEX) __PYX_CONST_CONDITION(PY_VERSION_HEX >= VERSION_HEX)
```
which does not work inside #ifdefs, but would simplify the usage inside if statements.
Does this indirection prevent any compilers from actually optimizing the relevant branches away (which is quite important)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef __PYX_CONST_CONDITION
+  static int __Pyx_const_condition(int b) { return b; }

comment_data.body:
As long as optimizations are activated any compiler I know will inline this call. Afterwards the same optimizations are performed as without this call. Obviously you can get the compiler to emit worse code e.g. by disabling inlining `/O2 /Ob0`, which I do not think is a concern. 

However the general consensus here appears to be to simply deactivate these warnings on MSVC in the utility code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -307,6 +307,12 @@
   #define __has_cpp_attribute(x) 0
 #endif
 
+/* This macro can be used to suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions */
+#ifndef __PYX_CONST_CONDITION
+  static int __Pyx_const_condition(int b) { return b; }

commit.message: Suppress warnings about constant conditional expressions

repo.description: Fork of Cython used in RapidFuzz for features, which are not supported in Cython
